FBIS4-28695      "dreas113_l_94001"        FBIS-EAS-94-113  Daily Report    13 Jun 1994      Philippines      Vaalco Affiliate To Conduct Spratlys Research      Vaalco Affiliate To Conduct Spratlys Research      BK1306052594 Hong Kong AFP in English 0516 GMT 13 Jun 94   BK1306052594    Hong Kong AFP    English     BFN     [Text] Manila, June 13 (AFP) -- The Philippine Government  has authorized an affiliate of the US firm Vaalco Energy Inc. to  conduct preliminary oil drilling research in the disputed  Spratly Islands, the Department of Energy said Monday.    The six-month permit allows Alcorn (Production) Philippines  Inc. to conduct "research and library work" on aeromagnetic  surveys and other data already held by the department, its oil  and gas division chief, Ismael Ocampo, said.    The permit covers the Kalayaan group of eight islands and  reefs currently garrisoned by Philippine troops.    Ocampo told AFP the permit, the first to be granted by  Manila  in the area, was "sensitive" due to conflicting territorial  claims on the strategic South China Sea chain by Brunei, China,  Malaysia, the Philippines, Taiwan and Vietnam.    Because of the territorial conflict, any eventual drilling  to  be permitted by Manila would have to be in a "joint venture with  China and Vietnam," he said, adding that no other Philippine oil  exploration firm has applied for permit in the Kalayaan area.    An Alcorn official, Ponciano Mathay, told AFP his company  has  applied for a permit to conduct research on the Kalayaan area,  but insisted the energy department had yet to approve it.    He said the permit would not require Alcorn to conduct  actual  drilling.    Two US firms, Crestone Energy and Mobil, are exploring for  oil in disputed areas in the South China Sea, with Crestone  enjoying the protection of the Chinese navy. Mobil obtained its  permit from Vietnam.    Alcorn is the operator of the West Linapacan offshore  production site off the western island of Palawan, the only  wells in commercial production in the Philippines.    Water intrusion has drastically reduced production to about  3,500 barrels per day from 15,000 bpd last year, but the  consortium plans to boost output to about 6,000 bpd following  the drilling of a sidetrack well last month.

FT932-1199 _AN-DFXCNAGNFT 930624   FT  24 JUN 93 / Commodities and Agriculture: Ghana hopes for Dollars 100m from gold mine sell-off      By LESLIE CRAWFORD      ACCRA   GHANA'S CASH-strapped government hopes to raise Dollars 100m this year through the sale of a 20 per cent stake of Ashanti Goldfields Corporation, the country's biggest gold producer jointly owned by UK-based Lonrho group and the government. Mr Emmanuel Agbodo, the head of Ghana's privatisation programme, said the government was calling for bids from interested mining companies. Ashanti Goldfields, he said, was 'conservatively' valued at Dollars 500m. The company produced 654,293 ounces of gold in the 1991-92 fiscal year, which ended in September. The target for the present fiscal year is 744,345 ounces. At present the government of Ghana owns 55 per cent of Ashanti Goldfields. Lonrho, with 45 per cent, also has the management contract for the mines. Mr Agbodo said the government planned to reduce its shareholding to about 35 per cent. The new partners would be required to accept Lonrho's operational control of the mines. The sale, which will be Ghana's biggest sell-off exercise to date, is being handled by the World Bank's International Finance Corporation. The projected Dollars 100m windfall has already been included in the government's 1993 budget. Without this pivotal source of income, the government risks derailing its carefully balanced budget - the cornerstone of World Bank-approved economic reforms. But Mr Agbodo conceded that the timing of the sale might not be to Ghana's advantage, as mining multinationals are unlikely to rush an investment decision of such magnitude. The proposed sell-off, however, underscores Ghana's commitment to pursuing one of the few privatisation programmes on the African continent. Mr Agbodo also confirmed that a Guernsey subsidiary of Gold Fields of South Africa had acquired a controlling stake of the government-owned Tarkwa underground gold mine for Dollars 2m. Tarkwa, in Ghana's western region, still has large reserves of low-grade ore, but has conducted virtually no exploration work in recent years. Gold Fields of South Africa is also looking into the possibility of purchasing the neighbouring Prestea gold deposits for a similar sum.   Companies:-  Ashanti Goldfields Corp.   Countries:-  GHZ  Ghana, Africa.   Industries:-  P1041 Gold Ores.   Types:-  COMP  Disposals.     COMP  Shareholding.  The Financial Times   London Page 30

FT932-14161 _AN-DDTCVAFYFT 930420   FT  20 APR 93 / Commodities and Agriculture: MIM covers all the options on Queensland deposit      By KEVIN BROWN      SYDNEY   MIM HOLDINGS, the Australian resources group, yesterday underlined its determination to acquire a substantial stake in the Ernest Henry copper-gold deposit in north-west Queensland by announcing a second conditional deal to buy the mining leases. The Ernest Henry deposit was discovered in 1991 by a joint venture between Western Mining Corporation and Hunter Resources on a group of six leases owned by Savage Resources, a small coal and exploration company. The deposit has indicated reserves of 69m tonnes of mineralisation at an average grade of 1.6 per cent of copper and 0.8 grammes per tonne of gold. However, its ownership is disputed between Savage Resources and the joint venture partners. MIM announced earlier this month that it had agreed to buy Hunter Resources' 30 per cent interest in the Ernest Henry deposit and the adjacent Mount Fort Constantine area in the event that the Queensland courts ruled against Savage. Under the second deal, announced yesterday, MIM would acquire 51 per cent of the deposit for ADollars 92.5m (Pounds 43.5m) if the courts ruled in favour of Savage Resources, or ADollars 14m for Savage's royalty rights if WMC and Hunter Resources are awarded ownership. Alternatively, the agreement provides for a range of royalty and equity transfers to MIM if the dispute between Savage and the joint venturers is settled out of court. Mr Norm Fussell, MIM's managing director, said that the group wanted to secure a substantial position in Ernest Henry as part of its basic strategic objective of expanding copper production, especially in its north-west Queensland base. The Ernest Henry deposit and the highly-prospective Mount Fort Constantine area are close to MIM's Mount Isa base, where the group has extensive mining and copper smelting facilities. In a separate announcement, MIM said that it would acquire the 13.5 per cent of the Oaky Creek export coking coal join venture that it does not already own from Hoogovens Delfstoffen of The Netherlands and Empresa Nacional Siderurgica of Spain.   Companies:-  MIM Holdings.   Countries:-  AUZ  Australia.   Industries:-  P1041 Gold Ores.   Types:-  RES  Natural resources.  The Financial Times   London Page 34

FBIS4-50656      "drchi098_e_94004"        FBIS-CHI-94-098  Daily Report    19 May 1994      Southeast Asia  Pacific      Petroluem Spokesman Rejects SRV's Accusation, Demands      Petroluem Spokesman Rejects SRV's Accusation, Demands      OW1905130194 Beijing XINHUA in English 1228 GMT 19 May 94   OW1905130194    Beijing XINHUA    English     BFN     [Text] Beijing, May 19 (XINHUA) -- The China National  Offshore Oil Corporation (CNOOC) today dismissed a Vietnamese  accusation that CNOOC had violated its sovereignty and rejected  its ensuing demands.    CNOOC Spokesman Chen Bingqian said at a press conference  today that the "Wan'an Bei-21" contract, signed in 1992 by CNOOC  and the U.S. Crestone Energy Corporation, over which Vietnam's  claim was made, is "legally binding."    He said the contract block, located in the Nansha [Spratly]  offshore area, falls within China's jurisdiction. "CNOOC and  Crestone have the right to undertake normal operations in this  area," he stated.    On April 25 a Vietnamese press release claimed Crestone and  CNOOC had "violated" the sovereign rights of Vietnam by signing  the contract for "Wan'an Bei-21" oil exploration.    It further demanded the termination of the contract and  cancellation of all related activities.    "Our company will absolutely not accept the accusation, as  well as the unreasonable demands," Chen said.    The "Wan'an Bei-21" contract covers an area of more than  25,000 square kilometers in the South China Sea. The  undersigner should be responsible for laying seismic lines and  drilling exploratory wells during the contractual period of  seven years.    "It must be pointed out that recently Vietnam Oil and Gas  Corporation has set aside a batch of blocks of the Nansha  islands for bids from foreign companies, and some foreign  companies have entered into contracts for oil and gas  exploration and exploitation, which constitute violations of  China's sovereignty over the Nansha offshore area and also  infringes on our company's interests," Chen warned.    "It is known to all that the Chinese Government has  repeatedly called for shelving the disputes and participating in  joint development before a solution to the Nansha issue can be  reached," he said.    Therefore, he said, "CNOOC welcomes relevant parties,  including Vietnam Oil and Gas Corporation, to cooperate with us  and to explore the possibility of joint development."

FT942-11689 _AN-EEDEHAGJFT 940504   FT  04 MAY 94 / Survey of Greater Philadelphia (10): Sun emerges from the clouds      By FRANK MCGURTY   Philadelphia loves a comeback story. It is a spirit epitomised in the movies by Rocky Balboa, the washed-up palooka who made the most of his last big shot to be somebody. In real life, there is no finer example than the impressive turnround by Sun Company, one of the stalwarts of Philadelphia's old industrial base. In 1991, the 108-year-old energy group - the fourth biggest company in the region - was a flabby under-achiever weighed down by a bloated portfolio of peripheral businesses. Overall, its operations were producing a meagre 2 per cent return on equity. Just two years later, the company is showing a return on equity of 10 per cent, having transformed itself into a lean contender with good prospects of sustained growth. 'They have identified where they have the best chance to be profitable,' says Mr George Baker, an analyst at Merrill Lynch in New York. 'In doing so, they have gone a long way towards making the company a more focused enterprise.' Sun has gone a long way in setting itself apart from its rivals, too. More than any other big energy group, it has emphasised a commitment to safe and sustainable environmental practices. It was the first Fortune 500 company to endorse the principles of the Coalition of Environmentally Responsible Economies, a non-profit organisation set up after the Exxon Valdez oil-spill to promote green business policies. On a smaller scale, Sun has put a human face on its corporate image with several innovative programmes, including an offer to buy and junk worn-out cars which are heavy polluters. In a small step which may symbolise the fresh approach, its headquarters was brought back to downtown Market Street after 23 years' exile in the suburb of Radnor. Nostalgia, however, had less to do with the relocation than did a desire to cut costs. The move was part of a comprehensive streamlining implemented soon after Mr Robert Campbell took over as chairman and chief executive in 1992. Under the new regime, the company has shifted its focus back to its traditional strengths - refining and marketing in the north-east. In its core operating region, Sun commands 14 per cent of the retail petrol trade, the second largest share behind Mobil. Branded petrol accounts for 37 per cent of total sales, by far the company's most important revenue generator. Sun hopes to build on these strengths. Concurrently, the group has withdrawn from the areas where it was taking a beating. It finally threw in the towel on most of its international exploration operations, after spinning off its US exploration and production in 1988. 'In drilling for oil and gas, we had a horrible record,' admits Mr Robert Aiken, chief financial officer. The company is still involved in international crude production, which remains profitable. Coal mining and real estate were deemed losing propositions, too. In Sun's continuing operations, expenses were slashed and the workforce reduced by 20 per cent to 14,000. So far, the results have exceeded Mr Campbell's goals. Sun posted operating profit of Dollars 193m last year, against Dollars 30m ayear earlier. The figure is well ahead of his target of achieving a Dollars 150m improvement. The company was again able to tap operating income in paying its dividend, another of the chairman's ambitions. Analysts are divided about some of the company's specific moves, and point out that its recovery is part of cyclical upturn by the industry as a whole. But most agree that the overall strategy is sound. Sun wins plaudits for securing long-term leases to operate filling stations along the Pennsylvania turnpike. The company also gained exclusive rights to sell petrol along the New Jersey turnpike, perhaps the most travelled highway in America. The high visibility of operating along such motorways carries benefits that exceed the revenues they directly generate, analysts say. Meanwhile, filling stations in the mid-west have been sold; underperforming outlets in the north-east have been pared from its 3,000-strong network. A move to integrate its branded petrol offerings under a single banner - Sunoco  - is also expected to pay off in higher margins, a critical factor in petrol retailing, where demand at best grows a scant 1 per cent a year. The group also put a feather in its cap by agreeing to buy a Chevron refining plant located on property adjacent to its main Philadelphia facility. The bargain-basement price of Dollars 170m made the deal an easy sell, even though the potential environmental remediation costs which Sun may face have yet to be quantified, says Mr John Hilton, an analyst at Argus Research in New York. 'Such investments are usually just shots in the dark,' says Mr James Murchie, who follows the industry for Sanford C Berstein in New York. He argues that future demand and margins on refined products are nearly impossible to gauge. Refining, a costly necessity for a marketer of petroleum products, continues to be a drag on Sun's bottom line, accounting for Dollars 80m in operating losses last year. Still, the Chevron acquisition was a safe bet, says Mr Murchie. Indeed, if the deal had been completed before this winter's deep freeze, which brought a sharp increase in demand for heating oil, the investment would have already paid for itself. FT942-15812 _AN-EDMEUAFHFT 940413   FT  13 APR 94 / International Company News: BHP to sell some mining assets to Western Metals      By NIKKI TAIT      SYDNEY   Broken Hill Proprietary, the large Australian steel and natural resources group, has agreed to sell certain mining and exploration interests in the Kimberley region of Western Australia to Western Metals. The assets for sale include a 58 per cent interest in the Cadjebut mine. Western Metals is a privately-owned company, in which Ausgold holds a 13 per cent stake. Ausgold, which asked for its shares to be suspended yesterday, said it had made an offer to acquire the remaining 87 per cent of Western Metals. It said it planned to raise ADollars 30m (USDollars 21.7m), via an underwritten public share offering, to fund the Cadjebut deal and the development of other assets included in the BHP transaction. The interests involved include BHP's stake in the Cadjebut zinc/lead mine, which was developed in 1987 and has about another 18 months of life. Total production at Cadjebut last year was 102,000 tonnes of zinc concentrate and 29,000 tonnes of lead concentrate. Also included in the package are undeveloped ore bodies at Blendevale, Twelve Mile Bore and Kapok, and interests in a number of joint ventures in the region. Ausgold said it hoped 'to bring on stream the development of the next ore body, 12 Mile Bore, before the existing reserves at Cadjebut are depleted'. BHP, which did not disclose the sale price, said the assets involved in the transaction no longer 'fitted our profile'. BHP's partner in the Cadjebut mine, with the remaining 42 per cent interest, is Shell Australia. The interest forms part of Shell's Australian metals portfolio, which the oil company has talked of floating on the stock market. CRA, the Australian resources group, yesterday announced it had agreed a 'farm-in' deal with Carpenter Pacific Resources (CPR), under which the latter can earn a 49 per cent interest in CRA's Hidden Valley gold project near Wau, in Papua New Guinea, for K35m (USDollars 36.9m). FT942-5664 _AN-EFCDVAC8FT 940603   FT  03 JUN 94 / Technology: Knowledge is power - Knova is an analytical tool that aspires to making the intangibles tangible      By DIANE PALFRAMAN   For most companies, improving business performance means reorganising to cut costs and jobs, followed by further investment in computers and communications technology. Few have considered the impact of intangibles such as knowledge on performance. Knowledge is a resource that is difficult to assess and manage. But now researchers at Cambridge University, working with British Petroleum, have developed a method for analysing the factors influencing knowledge. It allows an appropriate investment plan to be developed and, ultimately, the investment to be related to performance. BP initiated the work after making substantial organisational changes in the late 1980s. It wanted to improve the way people worked in a flatter, more team-oriented structure; but it also recognised that the usual information-based approach was too narrow and that 'soft' factors  - such as knowledge - must be taken into account. 'Common sense tells you that knowledge will influence the way people work, but we wanted to know how it affected them,' explains Paul Wilhelmij, BP International's team leader in decision support, who with his colleague, Jack Betteridge, provided a business focus for the work with Cambridge University. The partnership produced an analysis technique called Knova (Knowledge value-added). This provides 'a holistic business view to identify the less obvious cost drivers,' says Tony Holden, head of the university's decision support group, which collaborated in developing the method. Knova resulted in a computer model that takes into account the relationships  -in a team or organisation - between knowledge, people, performance, investment, culture and benefits. People factors include staff turnover and motivation, while culture factors include leadership, openness, informal and formal communications, the working environment, geographic distribution and personal reward. According to Holden, traditional management models have difficulty linking these 'soft' issues with 'hard' quantitative factors, such as costs and investment. Nor can they easily analyse the benefits of investing in the knowledge resource. In addition, Knova can provide both a static and a dynamic view of the factors that influence knowledge. By assigning order-of-magnitude values to the influencing factors and using system dynamic modelling software, a computer model can be produced. This model can then be used to track the factors over a period of time and perform 'what-if' analyses to compare different investment options. Knowledge investments cover, for example, new procedures, computer systems, communications, external consultancy and training. Holden points out that the computer model is only quasi-quantitative because of the subjective nature of such factors as culture, but insists: 'Knova facilitates a much richer representation, that can be linked to pictures, text and numbers, than the traditional paper-based representation of influencing factors.' Companies do realise that knowledge is important, says Holden. It is expertise, know-how, information and data that employees use to make decisions. In the recent restructuring, some companies have tried to use knowledge more effectively by introducing team-working and giving people more responsibility. But freedom to apply and share knowledge will not necessarily improve performance. Nor will an increase in the training budget. Knowledge must be developed and managed to produce beneficial results, argues Holden. The development of Knova began at the end of the 1980s and its practical relevance was tested in the early 1990s on projects within the exploration arm of BP. One application, that looked at human factors in team-working, involved an awareness campaign to overcome a common problem in oil exploration - when a drilling pipe gets stuck. At BP Exploration, the cost of this problem had risen sharply in the late 1980s, from around Dollars 32m (Pounds 21.5m) a year to nearly Dollars 40m in 1988. BP Exploration knew that poor communications was a leading factor in the problem. It developed a training programme to encourage open communication, knowledge-sharing and problem-solving among its drilling teams. It trained 800 people, 70 per cent of whom were from outside contractors. In two years, BP Exploration cut its drilling costs to Dollars 13m, but in 1991 costs began to rise again at two sites. This was put down to changes in personnel and a push for higher performance. Applying Knova to the problem (albeit after the fact) showed that Knova would have predicted the cost trends and would have highlighted staff turnover as a potential factor. Having validated the technique, both BP and the Cambridge group are applying it to other problems. BP is using it to look at operational decision-making on its process plants. 'We are trying to create the right kind of environment for people who are working together in teams on our plants,' says Wilhelmij. This would improve decision-making and could affect plant safety. At Cambridge University, the decision support group is currently using Knova to identify the influences on performance in service departments of large organisations, such as the UK's National Health Service hospitals. But the group's main target industries are manufacturing, in particular oil and petrochemicals, and financial services. These sectors have gone through big changes, and want to maximise performance and minimise risks. One way to do this, argues Holden, is by ensuring that people make quality decisions - decision-making being a knowledge-based activity. 'To get quality decisions, you may not need more sophisticated computer systems but a better organisational environment in which managers can make them,' says Holden. 'Investing in computer technology has become a knee-jerk reaction and although computers have a place companies must broaden their perspective. Companies must also consider the intangibles and our work is to make the intangibles tangible.'   Countries:-  GBZ  United Kingdom, EC.   Industries:-  P7372 Prepackaged Software. FBIS3-46294      "drchi018_t_94001"        FBIS-CHI-94-018  Document Type:Daily Report    27 Jan 1994      Northwest Region      Northwest Region Receives More State Investment    OW2601021494 Beijing XINHUA in English 0140 GMT 26 Jan 94   OW2601021494    Beijing XINHUA     Language:  English  Article Type:BFN     [Text] Yinchuan, January 26 (XINHUA) -- China has increased  state investment in the five northwestern provinces and  autonomous regions mainly inhabited by minority nationalities in  order to step up development of rich local natural resources and  promote economic prosperity.    Remarkable increases have been seen in both the amount and  the number of projects involving state investment in the  northwestern provinces of Gansu, Qinghai and Shaanxi and the  Xinjiang Uygur and Ningxia Hui Autonomous Regions.    So far, half of the fund for economic development of these  regions has come from state investment, which focuses on the  exploration and exploitation of coal and oil resources,  establishment of large state-owned enterprises and  infrastructure construction.    The five interior provinces and autonomous regions in  northwest China occupy one-third of the country's total  landspace. Among the 160 kinds of minerals found in China, 120  have been sited there.    Two out of the three newly-discovered large-scale natural  gas  fields are located in northwest China with the one in the basin  on the borders of Gansu, Shaanxi and Ningxia the country's  largest gas field ever found.    The plentiful natural gas of Shaanxi, the oil reserves of  Xinjiang, coal resources in Ningxia and the rich water power  resources of the Yellow River that winds through the region are  all of vital significance to the country's economic development.    Despite the area's rich natural resources, northwest China's  economic development has long lagged behind that of other parts  of the country for geographical and historical reasons.    Promotion of the local economy and exploitation of natural  resources has become an urgent need for the country. In China's  eighth five-year-plan, priority has been given to the  development of the transportation and electrical power  industries and the tapping of resources in northwest China.    Increased state investment has been rewarded with extensive  growth seen in electricity supplies, transporting capacity and  output of petroleum in the northwest region, which is expected  to become the country's number one energy supplier in the near  future.

FBIS3-40403      "jpest006__l94021"        JPRS-EST-94-006-L  Document Type:JPRS  Document Title:Science  Technology       Europe/International      18 February 1994   WEST EUROPE   BIOTECHNOLOGY      UK: Science Minister On Withdrawal of Gene Patents    BR1402155394 London Hermes Database in English 11 Feb  94--FOR OFFICIAL USE ONLY    BR1402155394    London Hermes Database     Language:  English  Article Type:BFN    [Speech by UK Science Minister William Waldegrave on 11  February 94, place not given: "Withdrawal of Gene Patents Good  For the UK"]    [Text] The withdrawal of patents for cDNA sequences for  unknown functions will encourage further research into this  important area, separating the exploratory research phase from  the exploration phase, Mr Waldegrave said today.    He was speaking following today's decision by the Medical  Research Council (MRC) and the US National Institutes of Health  (NIH) to withdraw their patent applications for cDNA sequences  of unknown function, filed in 1991.    Mr Waldegrave said:    "The MRC and NIH patent applications were filed in order to  protect the interests of the UK and US taxpayers, with least  damage to the international research effort in genome mapping  which requires the free flow of information.    "However, The Medical Research Council, with the support of  the Government, has always argued that these applications should  not be granted. I welcome the co-operation between the UK and  the US on this important issue and look forward to further  developments in this important area of research."    This announcement backs up MRC's decision in October 1993  not  to file any further patent application on newly-obtained cDNA  sequences of unknown function unless accompanied by knowledge of  the gene function.    Sir Dai Rees, Secretary to the MRC said:    "We feel this withdrawal of the patents is a correct step,  and we are delighted to be able to co-ordinate our actions with  those of the NIH." FBIS3-40552    "jpjst009__l94002"        JPRS-JST-94-009-L  Document Type:JPRS  Document Title:Science  Technology       Japan New Outlook for Space Industry     22 February 1994         New Outlook for Space Industry     MITI's Space Industry Policy   946C0001B Tokyo KIKAI SHINKO in Japanese Jul 93 pp  19-27--FOR OFFICIAL USE ONLY    946C0001B    Tokyo KIKAI SHINKO     Language:  Japanese  Article Type:CSO    [Article by Space Industry Section, Machinery and  Information Industries Bureau, Ministry of International Trade  and Industry]    [Text] Thanks to the progress made in international space  development efforts in recent years, topics related to space  technology are becoming increasingly familiar to the people. For  example, the images of cloud patterns over and around Japan,  which are sent by the meteorological satellite "Himawari," are  shown on television every day. The number of households  subscribing to satellite broadcasting service exceeds 4 million.  In addition, we are communicating with people in foreign  countries using the international telephone service offered via  communications satellites. In recent years, the use of the  global positioning system (GPS) satellite launched by the United  States is expanding from use on ships to use in cars, as well as  to portable use by individuals.    The space industry has been promoting the use of the space  technology that makes it possible to offer these services. The  industry comprises the space hardware production industry which  manufactures satellites and rockets, etc.; the space utilization  industry which offers broadcasting, communications,  meteorological and earth observation services; and the  space-related service industry which offers various services,  including database services using satellites. As their markets  continue to expand, these industries are beginning to experience  increased competition on the international market. Under these  circumstances, the Japanese space industry is experiencing a  turning point that is expected to continue up to around the year  2000.    The Ministry of International Trade and Industry (MITI) has  been promoting a number of programs aimed at encouraging the use  of space technology and services in Japan. These programs have  been promoted through increased cooperation with the  organizations devoted to promoting the use of space technology  and other space-related establishments in foreign countries. In  promoting these programs, the ministry took into consideration  the recent progress being made in global information exchange  services and the urgency of tackling the problem of the earth's  deteriorating environment. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------      Promotion of Utilization of Satellite-Based Remote Sensing  Technology    Remote sensing technology, which involves earth observation  from satellites, is one space technology in which the demand for  the technology is expected to increase for applications not only  involving meteorological observation, but also for natural  resource exploration, environmental observation and geographical  survey. Japan has launched a series of meteorological satellites  (GMS: Himawari) and a series of marine observation satellites  (MOS-1a and MOS-1b) to conduct space research and development  and to promote the use of space satellites. In February 1992,  Japan launched a natural resource exploration satellite (JERS-1)  that went into commercial operation that September. Japan has  exchanged memorandums for the joint operation of the satellite  with the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) of  the United States and the European Space Agency (ESA). In  November 1992, data received from the satellite was initially  supplied to researchers for AO verification. Talks are currently  under way between MITI and the National Space Development Agency  of Japan (NASDA) to make the data available to other customers.  In the meantime, there are plans to launch advanced earth  observation satellites (ADEOS-I and ADEOS-II) and a tropical  rainfall measuring mission (TRMM) satellite. There is also a  plan to participate in an international satellite launching  program in which Japan will provide the sensing equipment for  earth observation to be launched aboard a foreign-made  satellite. To strengthen the efforts toward natural resource  exploration and the observation of the natural environment to  grasp the effects industrial activities have on the environment,  MITI has been promoting the development of an optical sensor  (OPS) and a synthetic aperture radar (SAR) to be launched by the  JERS-1 satellite, the development of a  greenhouse-effect-causing-gas sensor (IMG) to be launched by the  ADEOS satellite, and the development of an advanced visible  light/infrared radiation sensor (ASTER) to be launched by NASA's  earth observation satellite (EOS-AM1). In addition, the ministry  is promoting the development of a next-generation synthetic  aperture radar (next-generation SAR) and a next-generation  greenhouse effect-causing gas sensor (next-generation IMG). At  the same time, the ministry is promoting the development of the  technology for the processing, analysis and utilization of the  data obtained from these satellites and sensors, and is  improving the system for distributing this data. Efforts are  also being made to construct a database of satellite observation  data and to construct a database network.    1. Development of Earth Resource Exploration Satellite  No 1 (JERS-1) JERS-1 is a satellite that was launched in  February 1992 for natural resource exploration using remote  sensing technology. The satellite was developed through joint  cooperation between MITI and NASDA. MITI has overseen the  development of the observation system, including the optical  observation sensor and synthetic aperture radar. The actual  development work has been commissioned to the Organization for  the Development of Natural Resource Exploration Systems (JAROS).  The development effort is now passing from the test operation  stage to commercial operation.    The JERS-1 satellite, equipped with synthetic aperture  radar,  is capable of performing multi-dimensional observation and of  conducting observation in short-wavelength infrared frequency  bands. The satellite is superior to those launched by the United  States and European countries, including LANDSAT and SPOT.  JERS-1 has drawn high expectations from researchers around the  world for its capabilities in natural resource exploration and  earth environment monitoring. Efforts are currently being made  by the Earth Resource Survey and Data Analysis Center (ERSDAC),  an extragovernmental organization affiliated with MITI, and  NASDA to improve the system to process, analyze and distribute  the data obtained from the satellite.    The data from the satellite is being received through the  cooperation of ground stations in the United States, Canada,  Australia and Europe. By receiving data from a European earth  resource survey satellite (EERS-1) for the ESA, Japan has  entered into a mutual cooperation agreement regarding satellite  data reception with those European countries. The European  satellite was launched in July 1991. A memorandum was exchanged  between ERSDAC and King Abdul Aziz City of Science and  Technology (KACST) of Saudi Arabia for the joint reception of  JERS-1 data and joint research between them. Research is  currently under way.    With the operation of the JERS-1 satellite, this joint  research is expected to produce useful results.    2. Development of Advanced Visible Light/Infrared  Radiation Sensor (ASTER)    ASTER is an optical observation sensor that is being  developed for a future launch aboard the JERS-1 satellite. A  similar sensor is scheduled to be launched in 1998 aboard the  U.S. satellite EOS-AM1 for earth observation. This satellite is  being developed by NASA. ASTER is currently under development by  JAROS, with the development commissioned to the establishment by  MITI. This sensor is an advanced version of the observation  sensor currently being used on the JERS-1 satellite. ASTER will  make it possible to conduct observation in multi-band  frequencies in the thermo-infrared frequency range for the first  time ever. This sensor is expected to be used in diverse  application fields, including natural resource exploration and  earth environment observation. In the United States, too, the  need to develop a sensor similar to ASTER has been voiced. The  fact that ASTER has been picked by NASA for launching aboard the  American satellite means that the Japanese sensor technology has  reached international standards. Considering that the sensor  will play an important role in the earth observation system  (EOS) project being promoted by NASA with cooperation from  Japan, Canada and European countries, the sensor has been  drawing great international attention. This has prompted the  formation of research teams not only in Japan, but also in the  United States with assistance from NASA, for developing  application fields for ASTER. MITI intends to promote the  development of the application fields through cooperation with  foreign researchers, including those from the United States and  Europe.    3. Survey of Earth's Environment Using  Satellite-Mounted Sensor (Wide-Area Environment Monitoring and  Surveying)    In recent years, the deterioration of the earth's  environment  has grown into a major international issue. The prime target of  the efforts to combat environmental pollution has been to  restrain the levels of substances in the environment which are  responsible for causing the so-called greenhouse effect. These  substances include CO[.sup]2[/] and methane. It is not yet  known in which part of the earth's environment these substances  are concentrated and in what density. The effort to monitor and  survey the earth's environment over a wide area will involve  earth observation using a satellite-mounted sensor (IMG) that is  capable of detecting these greenhouse effect-causing substances.  The earth observation satellite ADEOS is scheduled to be  launched by NASDA in 1995. The development of the sensor is  being conducted by JAROS, the construction of the ground system  for receiving IMG data is being conducted by ERSDAC, and the  development of data analysis technology has been undertaken by  the Central Research Institute of the Electric Power Industry.  All of these projects have been commissioned to these  establishments by MITI. The sensor is designed to measure the  distribution of these substances in vertical and horizontal  directions in the environment by detecting special types of  light in infrared wavelength ranges which are emitted by these  substances. This is the first time that an attempt to observe  the earth's environment using this method has been made, and  thus great attention is being paid by environmental specialists  around the world.    4. Development of Utilization Technology in Field of  Natural Resource Exploration    In the search for natural resources, including oil deposits,  it is important to comprehend the geological structure of a  particular region on the earth. The effort toward grasping the  structure combines the surveying of the earth's surface features  and boring. Until recent years, surveying was conducted by  dispatching specialists to a designated region and having them  conduct their tasks using exploration instruments. Recently,  aerial exploration using aircraft has begun to be conducted to  improve efficiency, enabling a larger area to be explored at one  time. Exploration from a satellite in space makes it possible to  cover an even greater area by scanning the earth's surface at  regular intervals. This new method has raised expectations among  those involved in such exploration.    MITI has been making an effort to make it possible to use  the  observation data obtained from LANDSAT and SPOT in the  exploration of natural resources, including exploration for oil  deposits. The development of the technology needed to promote  this effort has been conducted by ERSDAC as part of a  development task commissioned by MITI. So far, efforts have been  made to verify the effectiveness of the remote sensing  technology in exploring natural resource deposits by comparing  the data obtained by these remote sensing satellites with the  data obtained through ground exploration. In addition, the  development of the technology to improve the data processing and  analyzing techniques has been promoted to ensure the effective  use of the data. The use of the remote-sensed data has already  been started in the exploration of oil deposits and metal  resources, as well as in the exploration of geothermal energy.  The application field is expected to expand in the future with  further progress in the RD of remote sensing technology.    In June 1992, JERS-1 began to be used for practical  applications, and efforts are currently being made to adapt a  data processing method for the satellite. At the same time, the  development of the technology needed to process and analyze the  data obtained from ASTER is under way in cooperation with the  EOSDIS data processing and distribution system of the United  States. ASTER will be put into commercial operation in 1998.    So far, Japan has lagged behind other  technologically-advanced countries in developing the technology  to use remote-sensed data. However, it is expected that the  number of customers using the data will increase in the future  as a result of the improvement of data utilization systems.  Efforts to improve the system are currently under way in  preparation for the reception of data from JERS-1 and ASTER.    5. Development of Data Utilization Technology in Field  of Hydropower Development    In formulating a hydropower development plan, it is  essential  to grasp the available flow rate of water in a river. So far,  data on flow rates has been obtained by measuring the flow rates  at the measurement stations located along major rivers. Flow  rate calculations have been conducted by taking the river  surface area and other necessary elements into account. However,  there are many rivers in which it has been difficult to grasp  the flow rate due to a lack of measurement stations, as well as  for other reasons. Under these circumstances, in 1991 MITI  started to develop a method for calculating the flow rate in  Japan's rivers using the data obtained from remote sensing  satellites.    Promotion of Use of Microgravitational  Experiment Environment    A microgravitational environment prevents the convection  resulting from the presence of temperature differences from  occurring. Such an environment also prevents the separation of  materials due to differences in the specific gravities of these  materials. These advantages of a microgravitational environment  are expected to offer a better environment for experimentation  that will contribute to understanding physical phenomena better  and to the development of new useful materials. To ensure the  continued progress of space development, it is important to  understand the effects on the human body of living in a  microgravity environment for long periods of time. For the  purpose of better understanding these effects, experiments  within a microgravity environment must be stepped up in the  future. Microgravity conditions lasting for a very short time,  i.e., ranging from a few seconds to several minutes, can be  created during free falls from high towers, during ballistic  flights by airplanes, and by using a sounding rocket. However,  the microgravity conditions created using these media are not  sufficient for conducting experiments to develop new materials  or for conducting experiments involving living creatures. This  makes it essential for these experiments to be conducted in  space. NASDA has conducted research aboard the space shuttle by  seeking the cooperation of the United States. NASDA plans to  conduct experiments aboard the space station projected for the  future. In parallel with these efforts, MITI, in cooperation  with other research organizations, has been promoting the  development of an unmanned space experiment system (free flyer)  and self-returning unmanned space experiment system. At the same  time, the ministry is trying to make it easier for those  involved in space research to use their free-fall tower facility.    The experiment conditions experienced under a microgravity  differ greatly from the conditions encountered on the ground. In  order to promote the development of space technology under  microgravity, it is important to accumulate the sufficient basic  data needed to conduct the experiments smoothly. With this  understanding, MITI has been providing assistance to the Space  Environment Utilization Research Corporation and other  establishments engaged in the development of space technology.    1. Development of Free Flyer    In cooperation with the Education Ministry (Institute of  Space and Astronautical Science) and the Science and Technology  Agency (NASDA), MITI has been developing an unmanned free flyer  for conducting earth observation and conducting experiments  under microgravity conditions in space. The flyer is scheduled  to be launched by the H-II rocket in early 1995. It will be  recovered by the space shuttle that will be sent up to the  flyer's orbit six months after the flyer's launch. During this  period, various experiments will be conducted using the flyer,  with the results of the experiments expected to make it possible  for us to better use the microgravity space experiment  environment. The space flyer will play an important role as a  space experiment facility in preparation for the future  construction of a space station. The experimental equipment to  be installed on the flyer will have a modular design, which will  make it easy to replace the equipment units and the specimens  for reuse of the flyer. By employing the flyer for unmanned  experiments, the experiment environment aboard the vehicle will  be made free from the changes in gravity caused by crew  movements. This will make it possible for the flyer to realize  an experiment environment superior to that aboard the space  station. Another advantage of the flyer is the availability of  sufficient electric power to run the onboard instruments since  it will be equipped with solar batteries. MITI plans to include  experimental units involving three types of furnaces, i.e., a  single heat-source furnace, a combination heat-source furnace  and a focused-heat furnace, as an onboard experiment system to  produce high-purity GaAs crystals. GaAs, as a composite  semiconductor material, has a promising future for use in solar  electric power generation.    The efforts to develop a free flyer are currently at the  final stages of creating a flight model.    2. Development of Self-Returning Unmanned Space  Experiment Vehicle    The free flyer will provide an ideal microgravity experiment  environment. However, its disadvantages include inflexibility of  operation since it must be recovered by launching a space  shuttle, and safety requirements since the orbiting flyer must  be pulled into the cargo bay of the space shuttle by the crew  for recovery. Taking these disadvantages into consideration,  MITI plans to develop a self-returning unmanned space experiment  vehicle by seeking cooperation from the Education Ministry  (Institute of Space and Astronautical Science) and the German  government. With the self-returning vehicle, it will be possible  for Japan to launch and recover the vehicle for reuse without  requiring the help of other countries. The vehicle will provide  a solution to the problems encountered in the unmanned free  flyer. Considering the cloudy future of the space shuttle  operation, it will be necessary for Japan to develop such a  self-returning experiment vehicle. The disadvantages of the  self-returning vehicle are the limited supply of electric power  and the shorter experimental period during a single flight.    With the development of the self-returning vehicle, it will  become possible to launch experimental equipment with a total  weight of approximately 160 kg for conducting various  experiments under microgravity conditions for about a week.  Using the vehicle, it will also become possible to conduct  experiments to produce catalysts with better performance and to  evaluate the performance of carbon materials by exposing them to  the heat generated by the vehicle's re-entry into the earth's  atmosphere. Japan has yet to master the skills for recovering a  flying object from orbit. Success in the recovery will  contribute greatly to Japan's efforts in developing space  technology.    3. Positive Use of Free-Fall Experiment Tower    A free-fall tower for realizing microgravity conditions on  the ground, offering the greatest free-fall distance in the  world and which was constructed at a former coal mine in  Kamisunagawa Town on Japan's northernmost main island of  Hokkaido, was first used for experiments in September 1991.  Construction began in 1988, with the project undertaken by the  Underground Weightless Experimentation Center, a consortium of  the New Energy Development Organization (NEDO), local  governments and private companies. A free-fall tower makes it  possible for microgravity conditions to be realized repeatedly  on the ground relatively easily. Such a facility has been very  useful in conducting experiments in preparation for the  full-scale experiments to be conducted in space. For this  reason, free-fall towers are being used by space research  centers in many countries, including Bremen University in  Germany and NASA's (Louis) Research Center.    The Kamisunagawa free-fall tower has a free-fall distance of  approximately 500 meters and can produce a microgravity of  10[.sup]-4[/] lasting for 10 seconds. The availability of the  tower is expected to greatly boost Japanese research on the use  of the microgravity experiment environment.    Study is currently being conducted to promote joint space  research using the Kamisunagawa facility. Regarding one such  projected research project, MITI is considering conducting joint  research with Germany and France to develop the technology for  controlling furnace combustion under microgravity conditions,  aimed at applying the technology to the development of a  high-performance industrial furnace. As for another such  research project, the ministry is considering conducting joint  research with the United States to develop the technology for  controlling fuel combustion under microgravity conditions for  possible application to aircraft and space transport systems.    4. Activity of Space Technology Corporation    The Space Technology Corporation (STC) was founded in 1986  to  promote research and tests for creating and processing the  crystals for producing composite semiconductors under  microgravity conditions, and, consequently, to promote the  development of an advanced electronic technology. STC, an RD  company, is capitalized 70 percent by the Japan Key Technology  Center, with the rest handled by private companies. The company  has been conducting research under microgravity conditions by  launching small TEXUS rockets produced in Germany. STC's  research has focused on obtaining basic data that can only be  obtained under microgravity conditions. In the research  conducted by launching the small rockets, many useful data items  have been obtained. In particular, a feat in which the thermal  conductivity of InSb fluid was measured accurately drew  international attention. It had been impossible to obtain such  accurate thermal conductivity measurements on the ground due to  thermal convection and other effects. Considering the fact that  this kind of data is essential for growing the crystals used in  producing composite semiconductors and for the processing of the  crystals, systematic efforts must be made to accumulate such  data.    When the space shuttle Columbia was launched in 1993, STC  conducted experiments to develop new materials by participating  in the D-2 program. (The D-2 program involved experiments  conducted under microgravity conditions in the quarters aboard  the space shuttle that had been hired by Germany.) The  experiments conducted by STC involved obtaining the basic data  that will become necessary when developing new semiconductor  materials. The results of the experiments are expected to be  published in autumn 1993.    STC is the first Japanese company established to develop the  utilization of the microgravity environment of space. In this  sense, STC must assume a leadership role in the effort to  develop Japan's space industry.    5. Activities of Other Related Organizations in  Promoting Use of Space Environment    The Japan Society for the Promotion of Machine Systems  (JSPMS) has been developing small experiment systems to be used  aboard the space shuttle by taking advantage of the microgravity  conditions lasting six to seven minutes that were made available  during the launching of the small Swedish MASER rockets and  NASDA's small TR-IA rockets. In March 1989, with the cooperation  of the Society of Japanese Aerospace Companies, Inc. (SJAC),  JSPMS conducted experiments on molded oxide semiconductor  materials and conducted on-the-spot observation of this  material's crystallization process aboard these rockets. In  April 1992, the JSPMS conducted a second series of experiments.  JSPMS is scheduled to conduct experiments during the September  1993 flight of a TR-IA rocket to unravel the mechanism of the  fluid phenomenon accompanying the boundary phenomenon.    On the other hand, SJAC has been involved in conducting  experiments to grow zeolite crystals aboard a German satellite,  in addition to extending its cooperation to JSPMS in the  experiments described above.    In May 1993, SJAC conducted experiments aboard the Russian  space ship Mir in which they grew crystals of proteins. These  experiments have been conducted under limited weightless  conditions. However, MITI wants the publication of the results  of these experiments to lead to recognition by the industries  and researchers concerned of the importance of promoting the  utilization of microgravity conditions.    In the meantime, the Japan Space Utilization Promotion  Center  (JSUP) has been actively introducing the results of research on  the utilization of microgravity environments conducted in Japan  and abroad, as well as research trends.    Promotion of the Development of Space Plane-Related  Technology    In order to promote space development, it is important to  substantially cut the costs of ferrying men and equipment  between the ground and space. To realize this, it is necessary  to step up the development of a space plane (space shuttle) that  can be used repeatedly. Current efforts are centered around the  development of space shuttle-type transport systems launched by  nonreusable rockets. A number of countries are currently  developing space plane-type vehicles, including Hermes being  developed by the European Space Agency and Home being developed  by Japan. In the United States, the development of a completely  reusable space plane that will take off and land just like an  ordinary aircraft is already underway.    The most difficult part of developing the space plane is the  development of the materials for use in the engines and fuselage  that must withstand temperatures approaching 1,800C. In  preparation for the development of such materials, MITI has  conducted a series of investigations of developments occurring  between 1987 and 1990. In addition, MITI has promoted such  development through the RD Project of Basic Technologies for  Future Industries ("Next Generation Project") being undertaken  by the government's Agency of Industrial Science and Technology,  and by promoting efforts through its program for the Improvement  of RD Infrastructures being launched by the New Energy  Development Organization (NEDO).    1. Development of Advanced Super-High  Temperature-Withstanding Materials    The Agency of Industrial Science and Technology kicked off  an  eight-year project in 1989 to develop advanced super-high  temperature-withstanding materials as part of the agency's  endeavors in the Next Generation Project. The interdisciplinary  project involves researchers from the agency's laboratories, the  nation's universities, and private companies who are developing  materials with super-high temperature-withstanding and good  antioxidation capabilities suitable for use in constructing the  space plane. The materials under development include Ti-Al and  Nl-Al intermetallics, as well as composite materials reinforced  with carbon or silicon carbide fibers.    This project has attracted considerable interest from  foreign  companies. So far, a number of foreign companies, including  Rolls-Royce, have participated in the project by extending  cooperation to the Research and Development Institute of Metals  and Composites for Future Industries (RIMCOF), an organization  representing the private sector that is responsible for  promoting the project.    2. Activities of Japan Ultra-High Temperature Materials  Research Center (JUTEM)    As part of the project of Improvement of RD  Infrastructures,  JUTEM was established to help NEDO with the development of  super-high temperature-withstanding materials. The center is  responsible for making the facilities needed to produce  super-high temperature-withstanding materials and to evaluate  the materials developed that are available to Japanese and  foreign researchers.    The center has two regional centers--one in Ube City,  Yamaguchi Prefecture, and the other in Tajimi City, Gifu  Prefecture. The former is mainly equipped with production  facilities, while the latter mainly holds evaluation facilities.  The operation of these regional centers is being subsidized by  local governments and the companies using the centers. A portion  of the facilities at these centers became operational and  available for RD use in April 1991. It is expected that  these  centers will serve as the nucleus of regional activities for the  developing advanced technology industries.    The facilities installed at these centers have drawn  considerable attention from foreign researchers. So far, many  researchers from foreign countries have visited these centers.    Promotion of Development of Space Robot Technology    The effort directed toward space development so far has  relied mainly on manned space programs, including the Apollo  space program and programs involving the use of the space  shuttle and Mir spaceships. In order to promote space  development further, it will be essential to develop space  robots. The robots will make it possible to perform various  hazardous space tasks for the astronauts, including satellite  maintenance in orbit and constructing a large-scale space  station at comparatively low cost.    In fact, it has been found that the space station program  (preparation for it is under way, aiming at starting space  station operation in the late 1990s) will involve vast amounts  of construction and maintenance work that will be more than the  astronauts can handle. This has caused the program to be  completely reviewed.    The need for the introduction of space robots will become  more important in the larger-scale space station programs needed  in the future for the exploration of the moon and Mars.    In the meantime, Japan lags behind Canada in the development  of space robot technology. (Canada developed the robot arms  currently being operated from the space shuttle.) However, Japan  has a reached the top level of industrial robot technology, and  its potential ability in robotics has been highly evaluated  internationally. In 1990, the United States and France each sent  fact-finding missions to Japan to investigate the Japanese  situation regarding the development of space robot technology.  As described above, international cooperation in the field of  space robot technology has begun to be promoted in recent years.    Under these circumstances, MITI plans to start research on  space robot technology so that it can evaluate the fundamental  technology needed to create space robots by taking advantage of  the launch of technology evaluation satellite No 7 (EST-VII),  scheduled to be launched by NASDA in 1997.    Joint research by Japan and the United States on a technique  for mutual manipulation of a telerobot installed a very long  distance away was scheduled to start in 1993.    Study of Electric Power Generation System in Space    Amid the mounting concern in recent years about the  deterioration of the earth's environment, the Japanese  government has announced that it will make an effort to  formulate a plan to save the earth from aggravating  environmental pollution, that it will promote the transfer of  environment-related technologies to developing countries, and  that it will promote the development of new energy-related  technologies that may prevent environmental pollution from  causing further aggravation. The space electric power generation  scheme involves generating electric power using solar energy,  and transmitting the electric power thus generated to ground  stations in the form of microwave energy. This energy generation  system represents one of those new energy generation methods  being studied for possible introduction in the future in our  effort to save the earth from environmental destruction. In  order to realize electric power generation from space, a number  of problems must be resolved. These problems include the  development of a technology for constructing a large-scale  electric power generation system in space, grasping the effects  on the earth's environment of using microwaves to send the  electric power generated, and reducing the cost of constructing  such a system. Technologically, however, a major hurdle has  almost been cleared, and it is highly possible that electric  power generation from space will be realized. Since 1991, MITI  has been conducting surveys on space electric power generation  system development in Japan and abroad, on the technological  possibilities of constructing such systems, and on their  economic viability.    Study of Launching Rockets on Commercial Basis    As a result of the progress being made in recent years in  the  commercial utilization of communications and broadcasting  satellites worldwide, rockets for placing these satellites in  orbit are beginning to be launched on a commercial basis by  Ariane Space Corporation and other companies. In the meantime,  with the appearance of a company established to procure rockets  and launch them for its customers, it will become possible to  launch rockets on a commercial basis in Japan. The company was  founded by setting sights on the launch of the H-II rocket that  is under development by NASDA.    However, in order to make it possible to launch rockets on a  commercial basis in Japan, a number of problems must first be  solved. These problems include revising the space law with  respect to clauses defining the responsibility of third parties,  improving the rocket launch center utilization system,  transferring rocket-related technologies currently held by  governmental organizations, adjusting interests with fishermen,  and developing the demand to ensure that rocket launching will  continue on a commercial basis.    Since 1993, MITI has been making an effort to realize the  launching of domestically-developed rockets on a commercial  basis.    Survey of Situation of Development of Next-Generation  Commercial Satellites and Their Utilization    The need for developing next-generation commercial  satellites  has been mounting in recent years. For example, in the case of  satellites for observing the earth's environment, disaster areas  and conditions on the ground, the next-generation satellites  will make it possible to establish more sophisticated earth  observation systems that will allow observation to be realized  at greater frequencies. However, many problems must still be  solved before development can proceed. These problems include  who will develop and operate the satellites, how the satellite  services will be operated, and other problems expected to be  encountered in promoting international cooperation in the  development and utilization efforts.    In preparation for such development, MITI has been  conducting  surveys since 1991 on the situation in Japan and abroad with  respect to the development of advanced commercial satellites,  focusing on ones to be used in earth observation. Parallel to  this, the ministry has been studying the measures it will  introduce to promote the development and use of the satellites  on a commercial basis.    Problems MITI Must Tackle To Promote Space Development    So far, this report has introduced the current situation in  the Japanese space industry that is experiencing a turning point  in various respects, and the efforts MITI has been making to  promote space development. There are still many problems that  must be tackled in promoting the commercial utilization of space  technology and international cooperation.    These problems include:    1. Improvement of the Industrial Infrastructure for  Better Market Competitiveness    The space industry depends heavily on government subsidies.  The Japanese space industry has not had sufficient  commercial-base experiences in its activities. Taking these  things into consideration, it is important for the industry to  promote the use of parts and hardware systems in actual space  applications, and to accumulate data on the results of actual  use. Improvement must also be made in the production and test  systems necessary to produce satellites and rockets. In  addition, the industry must formulate a corporate strategy that  will take international cooperation and the international  division of space development tasks into account.    2. Promotion of Utilization of Space Technology    An urgent task involves developing a technology that will  promote the use of the data obtained from the remote-sensing  satellites in industrial applications, and reforming the  administrative system to facilitate the commercial use of the  data. It is important to promote experiments in microgravity  conditions, including experiments using free-fall towers.  Efforts must be made to develop the demand for ground-use as  well as space-use equipment and systems.    3. Establishment of Framework for Commercial Use of  Space    The industry must strengthen competitiveness in the  international market. At the same time, the Japanese government  must take measures to promote space development and the  utilization of space technology in the private sector. Such  measures would include the legislation of laws governing the  commercial launching of rockets in compliance with the space  treaty and ensuring the availability of rocket launch centers  that can be used year-round.

FBIS4-33214      "drlat107_l_94002"        FBIS-LAT-94-107  Daily Report    3 Jun 1994      Bolivia      Roundup of Economic Reports      Roundup of Economic Reports      PY0306001494   PY0306001494       BFN       [Editorial Report] The following is a compilation of  reports on economic activities in Bolivia monitored through 2  June.    Central Bank President Fernando Candia has reported that the  fiscal deficit dropped by 206 million bolivianos in real terms  during the first quarter of the year. He noted that public  sector expenses dropped by 86 million bolivianos and that  revenues rose by 120 million Bolivianos during this period. He  said exports rose by 34 percent while imports rose by just 3.8  percent. The balance of payment deficit dropped 80 million  bolivianos compared with the same period in 1993. (Santa Cruz EL  MUNDO in Spanish 21 May 94 National Section p 2)    The trade balance foreign reserve account amounted to $504  million in the first four months of the year, registering a $4  million surplus. Exports totaled $130.2 million and money  deposited in banks over exports amounted to $209.7 million.  (Santa Cruz EL MUNDO in Spanish 23 May 94 National Section p 3)    The Muller Inc. consulting firm has reported that, in spite  of difficulties in the financial sector, the banking system is  showing a significant increase which guarantees financial  stability. The group of largest banks have resources of over  $400 million, middle-sized banks have between $200 million and  $400 million, and small banks have less than $200 million.  (Santa Cruz EL MUNDO in Spanish 26 May 94 National Section p 1)    Edmundo Salvatierra, the Bolivian Government Oil Deposits  [YPFB] industrial manager, has disclosed that the YPFB plans to  invest some $23 million this year to explore, produce, and store  crude oil and natural gas in the tropical region of Cochabamba  department. Salvatierra said the Finance and Economy  Development Ministry has approved YPFB investments worth $103  million throughout the country. The projects involve  exploration in Carrasco and Katari deposits and the Ivirza XI  well, production in Carrasco X-5 and Carrasco X-6 wells, and the  storing of crude oil extracted from Surubi, Carrasco, Katari,  and Bulo Bulo oilfields that will be sent to Cochabamba and  Santa Cruz. (La Paz PRESENCIA in Spanish 27 May 94 Second  Section p 1)

FBIS4-53380      "dreas097aa_94003"        FBIS-EAS-94-097  Daily Report    19 May 1994      INTERNATIONAL AFFAIRS      International Business Conference in Singapore      International Business Conference in Singapore      PRC Vice-Premier on Spratlys    BK1905074894 Hong Kong AFP in English 0741 GMT 19 May 94   BK1905074894    Hong Kong AFP    English     BFN     [Text] SINGAPORE, May 19 (AFP) -- Chinese Vice-Premier Li  Lanqing indicated Thursday that Beijing had no intention of  reversing its decision to give a US oil company rights to  explore for oil in territory disputed with Vietnam. Li said  that while Beijing would continue "friendly consultations" with  Hanoi on overlapping territorial claims in the South China Sea,  these talks would cover only disputed territories, not territory  belonging to China.    "In regards to indisputable territories, there is no  question," he told a business opportunities conference here  organised by the New York-based Asia Society. Li was asked  whether China would keep a pledge to its Southeast Asian  neighbours to keep the peace over territorial disputes in the  Spratly islands. The islands, which reputedly sit atop vast  deposits of oil and gas, are claimed in whole or part by Brunei,  China, Malaysia, the Philippines, Taiwan and Vietnam.    Crestone, a Colorado-based oil company, announced last month  that it planned to drill into the Tu Chinh sandbar, about 400  kilometers (250 miles) southeast of Vietnam's coast, under terms  of a concession signed with China. But Vietnam, which claims  that the Tu Chinh sandbar is well within its special economic  zone and continental shelf, has demanded Crestone halt all  operations in the area, saying any exploration was illegal.    Li welcomed remarks by Vietnamese Prime Minister Vo Van Kiet  at the same conference Wednesday that Hanoi would pursue its  claims in the South China Sea "through peaceful negotiations and  in an atmosphere of friendship." He said that Beijing still  believed that claimants should jointly develop disputed areas.    Kiet told the STRAITS TIMES daily in an interview published  Thursday that while Hanoi would defend its territory, it saw no  reason to use force in Tu Chinh because of improvements in ties  with China. The Chinese and Vietnamese navies fought a brief  but bloody engagement in the Spratlys in March 1988. Hundreds  of Vietnamese were believed to have been killed in the fighting.

FT941-10165 _AN-EBJCNAGAFT 940210   FT  10 FEB 94 / Commodities and Agriculture: International consortium to seek oil in China's Tarim basin      By TONY WALKER      BEIJING   Agip of Italy and Texaco of the US, at the head of an international oil consortium, have initialled an agreement to explore in the vast Tarim basin area of China's remote western region. Mr William Doyle, Director of Texaco China, described the 9,814 sq km Tarim bloc as a 'world class opportunity' for the five-member partnership, in which Agip will be the operating company. Other members of the consortium include Elf of France and two Japanese companies - Japan Energy Company and the Japan Petroleum Exploration Company. Each partner will have 20 per cent. Mr Doyle said he was aware of suggestions that China was offering less prospective areas in the Tarim basin to foreign participation, but Texaco was 'very pleased' with the potential of its concession, which lies at the western end of five being made available to foreign companies. China announced about a year ago that it was inviting foreigners to explore in promising onshore areas including the Tarim, which had long been eyed by the international petroleum industry as potentially 'one of the world's last great oil plays'. Response from foreign companies has been lukewarm, however, compared to the enthusiasm that greeted the opening of China's offshore areas in the early 1980s. Among factors dampening enthusiasm have been worries about lack of infrastructure in the Tarim and uncertainty about the construction of a pipeline to transport oil from the remote region. Mr Doyle said he was confident that if oil was discovered in commercial quantities that the Chinese would ensure that transport would be facilitated. He estimated a 2,000km pipeline across some of the world's roughest terrain would cost 'several billions'. Texaco has been relatively successful in its Chinese ventures. With its partners Agip and Chevron of the US, it is producing 60,000 barrels a day in the South China Sea. The American company recently signed agreements to explore in the East China Sea south of Shanghai. It is also involved in exploration in the Bohai Gulf, south-east of Beijing.
